items.content:
#â€‹583 â€” March 8, 2023 | Read on the web

An End to Typographic Widows on theÂ Web â€” The new text-wrap:balance declaration (defined in CSS Text Module Level 4) is currently shipping in Chrome Canary, and is soon to be in Blink-based browsers including Edge. Itâ€™s a relatively new bit of CSS which promises to all but end typographicÂ widows (single overhanging words on new lines â€“ really an orphan in this case). Tyler Sticka also looks at the headline balancingÂ potential.

Richard Rutter

2023 Web Framework Performance Report â€” The folks working on the up and coming Astro Web framework looked at data from over 100,000+ real websites to understand how different frameworks actually perform in the real-world across core web vitals, Lighthouse andÂ more.

ğŸš€ In related news, the Astro project has unveiled an all new look.

It's everything you need to continue your journey to become effective atÂ JavaScript.

Be aware of it and donâ€™t actually do it, ofÂ course.

On Container Queries, Responsive Images, and JPEG-XL â€” Now that one major element of CSS Container Queries has shipped in nearly all modern browsers, Jason notes that itâ€™s time to revisit responsive images and ask how they fit in a container query world. Are we on the rightÂ path?

Zoran Jambor

Intro to HTML-First Frontend Frameworks â€” The post defines HTML-first front-end frameworks as ones that prioritize sending complete functional HTML versus a JavaScript bundle, and looks at some of the different approaches taken by different tools like Marko, Astro, Eleventy, andÂ Enhance.

SitePen Engineering

Akshay Khot

PDF:Â The Carbon Impact of Web Standards â€” This report brings together the findings of a systematic investigation into the carbon impact of web standards (such as frontend HTML and CSS). It shows how developers, tooling, and browser vendors can calculate how polluting their web presence is (in terms of electricityÂ usage).

Alexander Dawson

Why to Avoid Spanning Table Headers â€” Spanned table headers are not well supported across screenÂ readers.

Adrian Roselli

Design Systems in the Time of AI â€” Brad notes that it has â€œbeen absolutely wild to witness the rise of the new crop of AI toolsâ€, calling it equally exciting and terrifying. This post looks at how they may impact the world of design systems, and explores some obvious useÂ cases.

Brad Frost

You can adjust the values for the scrollbar-based pseudo-elements (which require -webkit- prefixes) and see the results directly on the page, before copying theÂ CSS. Nice, straightforward, and clean.

Henri Parviainen
